clusters.title: Information about Optus triple-0 outage scarce as state vents frustration over deaths
clusters.neutral_headline: Optus Outage Leads to Deaths and Scrutiny
bullet_summary: Reported by ABC News Australia, 9News, ABC Just In

items.title: Information about Optus triple-0 outage scarce as state vents frustration over deaths
items.standfirst: It's been two days since three people died after a devastating Optus outage caused hundreds of emergency calls to fail, but information about the incident remains scarce.
items.content: It's been two days since three people died after a devastating Optus outage caused hundreds of emergency calls to fail, but information about the incident remains scarce.

items.title: Newborn among the three dead in Optus Triple Zero failure
items.standfirst: South Australia Police have identified two of the three people who died after an outage led to 600 emergency service calls unable to go through to Triple Zero across WA, SA and the NT.
items.content: Three people died during an Optus outage yesterday, which impacted hundreds of Triple Zero calls across South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory.Two of the deaths took place in SA and another in WA, Optus chief executive Stephen Rue said in a snap press conference on Friday evening.SA Police say they've identified the two people in their state, with a newborn among the dead.READ MORE: SA state government's cabinet reshuffle makes history "The deaths involved an eight-week-old boy from Gawler West and, a 68-year-old woman from Queenstown," a statement said."The circumstances of each death, including any impact of the outage, are being investigated and a report will be prepared for the State Coroner in each case."Rue said the technical failure was the result of a network update issue and affected 600 Triple Zero calls on the network. Welfare checks were then conducted across today to all affected households after the issue was fixed, he added.READ MORE: Pilot's body recovered from plane crash wreckage in NSW national parkFrom those welfare checks it was established that three of the calls came from households where people passed away. "Our investigation is ongoing but at this stage I can confirm that approximately 600 customers were potentially impacted, of which a portion of calls did not go through," he said.He apologised to the families of those who passed away."I am so sorry for your loss What has happened is completely unacceptable. We have let you down. You have my assurance that we are conducting a thorough investigation. "This should not have happened."Minister for Communications, Anika Wells, labelled the incident "serious and completely unacceptable", vowing to "thoroughly investigate" the outage.READ MORE: Ex-MP's 'fall from grace' as victim tells of pain and fear "This is incredibly serious and completely unacceptable," Wells said in a statement."The impact of this failure has had tragic consequences and my personal thoughts are with those who have lost a loved one."Wells added that "all telecommunication providers have obligations to ensure they carry emergency services calls".Shadow Minister for Communications, Melissa McIntosh, said the failure was "deeply concerning"."Whilst Optus is still undertaking an investigation as to how this occurred, I am very concerned the emergency camp-on arrangements that should have been in place also failed," she said."There must be a full and thorough investigation into this incident, to establish how and why and most importantly – ensure this never happens again".Emergency services camp-on arrangements are designed to allow Triple Zero calls to be made even if one phone carrier has no network coverage in the area, by using another mobile network's services instead.Optus could face fines of more than $10 million and could be liable for other penalties.It's not the first time Optus has had a major outage.Optus was last year ordered to pay more than $12 million for breaches of emergency call rules in November 2023 following an investigation by the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA).The ACMA found Optus failed to provide access to the emergency call service for 2145 people during the course of the 14-hour outage on November 8, 2023.It said Optus then failed to conduct 369 welfare checks on people who had tried to make an emergency call during the outage.At the time the fine was issued, ACMA Chair Nerida O'Loughlin said significant penalty reflected the critical nature of the breaches."Triple zero availability is the most fundamental service telcos must provide to the public. When an emergency call fails to connect there can be devastating consequences for public health and safety," she said.Wells said the Australian Government had "accepted all recommendations from the previous Optus Outage Review and has fully implemented 12 of the 18 recommendations", with the remaining six recommendations still underway. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

clusters.title: Seven teenagers charged with murder over deaths of two Melbourne boys
clusters.neutral_headline: Seven Teenagers Charged in Melbourne Double Homicide

items.title: Seven teenagers charged with murder over deaths of two Melbourne boys
items.standfirst: Dau Akueng, 15, and Chol Achiek, 12, were allegedly attacked by a group of people wielding knives and machetes.
items.content: Seven teenagers have been charged with murder over the deaths of two children in Melbourne's west two weeks ago.Dau Akueng, 15, and Chol Achiek, 12, were allegedly attacked by a group of people wielding knives and machetes shortly before 8pm on Saturday, September 6 in Cobblebank.The pair were found critically injured about 200 metres apart, with Chol on Marble Drive and Dau on Cobble Street.READ MORE: Doctor who blew whistle on mushroom murderer sanctionedPolice carried out warrants at properties about 6am today.Police have since charged a 19-year-old Thornhill man, two 16-year-old boys and a 15-year-old boy with the murder of Akueng.A 19-year-old Caroline Springs man, an 18-year-old Wollert man and a 16-year-old boy have been charged with the murder of Achiek.READ MORE: 'Obscene': Driver given ticket for 'eight seconds' in parking spotCommunity leader Richard Deng issued a statement thanking police hours after the arrests were made."Today's arrests are great news and a relief not only to the South Sudanese community but also to the wider community," Deng said."The arrests will renew hope and trust in Victoria Police and the government.The community was left reeling in the wake of the boys' deaths and tributes remain at the spots where both of the boys died.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.standfirst: Hannah Thomas, who sustained an eye injury during an arrest at a pro-Palestinian rally, is awarded legal costs to the tune of nearly $22,000 after all of her charges were dropped.
items.content: Hannah Thomas, who sustained an eye injury during an arrest at a pro-Palestinian rally, is awarded legal costs to the tune of nearly $22,000 after all of her charges were dropped.

ai_summary: Hannah Thomas was injured during a protest.
She was an ex-Greens candidate.
She was awarded $22,000 in legal costs.
The charges against her were dropped.
The injury occurred at a pro-Palestinian rally.

clusters.title: China responds to Australia's defence treaty with PNG
clusters.neutral_headline: China Responds to Australia's PNG Defence Treaty

items.title: China responds to Australia's defence treaty with PNG
items.standfirst: China has urged Papua New Guinea not to sign any deal that might exclude or restrict third parties from cooperating with the Pacific nation, as Australia scrambles to clinch a landmark defence treaty.
items.content: China has urged Papua New Guinea not to sign any deal that might exclude or restrict third parties from cooperating with the Pacific nation, as Australia scrambles to clinch a landmark defence treaty.

ai_summary: China responded to Australia's treaty with PNG.
China urged PNG to consider all parties.
Australia is seeking a defense treaty.
China wants no exclusion of third parties.
The focus is on cooperation in the Pacific.

items.title: Chequers, scout groups and a dolls' house — day two of Trump's state visit in pictures
items.standfirst: As US President Donald Trump left Windsor to meet UK Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer, first lady Melania Trump spent the day with the Princess of Wales and Queen Camilla.
items.content: As US President Donald Trump left Windsor to meet UK Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer, first lady Melania Trump spent the day with the Princess of Wales and Queen Camilla.

She spent time with the Princess of Wales.
The visit included Chequers and a dolls' house.

clusters.title: Doctor stands by Erin Patterson 'sociopath' comments despite AHPRA sanction
clusters.neutral_headline: Doctor Stands by Comments on Erin Patterson

items.title: Doctor stands by Erin Patterson 'sociopath' comments despite AHPRA sanction
items.standfirst: The doctor who called triple murderer Erin Patterson a "crazy bitch" and a "sociopath" has been sanctioned by AHPRA, but says he does not regret making the comments about the mushroom murderer.
items.content: The doctor who called triple murderer Erin Patterson a "crazy bitch" and a "sociopath" has been sanctioned by AHPRA, but says he does not regret making the comments about the mushroom murderer.

ai_summary: A doctor made comments about Erin Patterson.
The comments described her as a "sociopath".
The doctor was sanctioned by AHPRA.
The doctor does not regret the comments.
Patterson is a triple murder suspect.

clusters.title: Surprise La Niña hints at another wet and stormy Australian summer
clusters.neutral_headline: La Niña Hints at Another Wet Australian Summer

items.title: Surprise La Niña hints at another wet and stormy Australian summer
items.standfirst: Australia's key drivers of weather variability are stacking up to produce another wet, severe-weather season, with an increased risk of flooding, thunderstorms and cyclones.
items.content: Australia's key drivers of weather variability are stacking up to produce another wet, severe-weather season, with an increased risk of flooding, thunderstorms and cyclones.

ai_summary: La Niña conditions are emerging.
This suggests a wet summer for Australia.
There is an increased risk of flooding.
Thunderstorms and cyclones are also likely.
Australia's weather variability is the focus.

clusters.title: Collapses expose deep flaws in Australia's $4.3 trillion super system
clusters.neutral_headline: Super System Flaws Exposed by Collapses

items.title: Collapses expose deep flaws in Australia's $4.3 trillion super system
items.standfirst: The failed First Guardian and Shield schemes have cost about 12,000 Australians more than $1 billion in retirement savings and exposed deep flaws in how Australia's $4.3 trillion superannuation sector is regulated.
items.content: The failed First Guardian and Shield schemes have cost about 12,000 Australians more than $1 billion in retirement savings and exposed deep flaws in how Australia's $4.3 trillion superannuation sector is regulated.

ai_summary: Collapses have exposed flaws in the super system.
The failed schemes are First Guardian and Shield.
About 12,000 Australians lost savings.
Over $1 billion in savings were lost.
The superannuation sector is worth $4.3 trillion.

clusters.title: 'How to keep the lights on' conversation totally ignores where we are already at
clusters.neutral_headline: Climate Solutions Exist Now, Do Not Require New Technologies

items.title: 'How to keep the lights on' conversation totally ignores where we are already at
items.standfirst: We don't have to wait for moonshot technologies to reach our climate targets. Most of the solutions to the climate crisis are already around us.
items.content: We don't have to wait for moonshot technologies to reach our climate targets. Most of the solutions to the climate crisis are already around us.

ai_summary: Many solutions to the climate crisis are already available for implementation.
The article emphasizes that waiting for new technologies is unnecessary.
Focus should be on utilizing existing solutions to meet climate targets.
The current conversation often overlooks readily available options.
Immediate action using current resources can address climate challenges.
